awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: Nudges in "Equilibrium"
awd_abstract_narration:
Programs using mass media to promote health have been evaluated individually.  While many of these programs have been shown to be effective, there is little research on how these programs interact with one another. This proposed research will study how different mass media programs to improve health interact with each other to affect other outcomes that were not targeted.  It will develop a theory and test it with an experiment in which individuals are randomly reminded or incentivized to engage in one healthy behavior, two healthy behaviors, or nothing at all. By comparing outcomes across these groups, the study will discover whether these mechanisms cause interference between programs, and if so, which mechanisms are most important. This is the first study that uses theory and experiments to study the general mechanisms that may produce interactions among interventions. The results of this study promise to directly help the beneficiaries of programs that promote healthy (or otherwise beneficial) behaviors in underserved communities by enabling policy makers to coordinate programs more effectively.  The results of this research will improve the performance of many government and business programs, thus improving the lives of many US citizens.

This research will study whether there are mechanisms that cause behavior change campaigns to have spillovers or interactions, identify those mechanisms, and understand their implications in dynamic settings in different domains.  Evidence of spillovers or interactions implies that campaigns can be made more effective through coordination.   The research will take inventory of theories in economics and psychology that predict spillovers or interactions, organize them into a simple framework, and test the predictions of the framework with a field experiment.  SMS reminder programs about one ``target'' behavior or two such programs will be sent to participants and compare responses to the effects on non-target behaviors to establish if interactions exist, and distinguish between several possible mechanisms. Two additional studies will: (i) explore how these mechanisms operate in a dynamic setting, and (ii) investigate when to expect spillovers or interactions.   The insights of behavioral economics have led many governments to establish "Nudge Units" to apply behavioral insights to policy. The results of this research project will further enhance the use of nudges to improve policy effectiveness in the US and around the world.   

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation?s intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Table 3 shows the results from the main estimating equations. During the treatment period, both sets of messages had strong positive effects on their target behaviors: meditation messages more than doubled the meditation rate (from 9.4% to 18.2%) and nutrition messages raised the daily rate of meal logging by almost 40% (from 11.8% to 28.3%). They also had negative spillovers on non-target behaviors: participants getting only nutrition messages meditated 29% less than the control group (6.6% relative to 9.4%) and participants getting only meditation messages logged meals 19% less than the control group (11.8% relative to 9.6%). There is no evidence of any interaction between the two sets of messages, neither for meditation nor for meal logging. Incentives for meal logging had large target effects, more than quadrupling the rate of meal logging (from 11.8% to 50%) as well as negative spillover effects on meditation that were similar in magnitude to the messages. These results imply that achieving a 1 standard deviation effect on meal logging costs 0.196 standard deviations of meditation via messages, and 0.075 standard deviations of meditation via incentives. Achieving a 1 standard deviation effect on meditation costs 0.23 standard deviations of meal logging via messages.

In the post-treatment period, effects of messages on target behaviors persisted, at 28% of their treatment-period magnitude for meditation and 18% for meal logging. Target effects of incentives also persisted, at 10% of their treatment period effect. Importantly, spillover effects of meal logging on meditation persisted at almost 100% of their treatment period effects. Spillovers of meditation messages on meal logging did not persist.

The intellectual merit of this research is substantial, as this is the first empirical evidence that behavioral interventions can have negative spillovers on other behaviors due to limited attention. It provides a proof of concept that such spillovers can exist for the particular behaviors and interventions that I used in my experiment, and motivates many additional questions. What types of behaviors "cost" attention to begin with? Does it depend on the extent to which the behavior is already a habit, or not? What types of behaviors draw from the same "pool" of attention? Do we only see spillovers when both behaviors are health-related, or do we see them for behaviors across different domains? To what extent to other types of interventions tax internal and external attention?

This broader impact of this research is also substantial. "Nudge Units" in governments around the world are facilitating behavior change interventions at a larger scale than ever before, often using (ever cheaper) communication technologies to notify, remind, and educate their target beneficiaries. This research poses an important caveat: when we use nudges to shift target behaviors, we should also take into account their effects on non-target behaviors. Limits to external attention mean that interventions involving informational, educational, or notifying components can have spillovers that are as large as one fifth the size of the target effect. And even when interventions place no demands on external attention, they can still generate spillovers via limited internal attention.

The outcomes of the project will include several presentations and at least one published paper (though this will not happen for some time). These outcomes will also constitute the bulk of my dissertation.
